column1: 234	haryana
column2: india -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- in a nation of more than a billion people and millions of unresolved court cases
column3: how do you take care of the backlog ? long distances over questionable roads stop many indians from making it into courtrooms . solution : you take the courts to the people . a bell rings . a bailiff yells out the name of the accused . it 's another day in the mobile courtroom of judge sandeep singh . his courtroom is a desk plopped down in the middle of a dusty schoolyard in the northern indian village of haryana . `` it works like any other regular court
column4: '' singh said . `` the only difference is that instead of people going to the court
column5: the court comes to the village . '' the mobile court is bused into rural areas to hear both criminal and civil complaints as part of an effort to dig the nation 's court system out from under an enormous backlog of cases . with an estimated 300 million unresolved cases languishing in indian courts
column6: one consultant believes
column7: it could take more than 300 years to clear the docket at the current pace . there 's one main reason for the backlog : inconvenience . people often have to travel long distances over questionable roads
column8: using slow modes of transportation . `` the witnesses -- definitely
column9: they do n't show up -- and even the parties -- they do n't show up -- and they send their advocate
column10: '' singh said . `` but here
column11: people are closer by
column12: so definitely it makes a difference . '' with distance no longer a problem
column13: more villagers and their attorneys are coming to hearings . compared to the traditional legal system
column14: the mobile court claims to be both fast and efficient . singh said he has been able to clear 1
column15: 100 cases in just six months time compared to 500 under the traditional court system . e-mail to a friend .

column1: 244	-lrb- cnn -rrb- -- despite the obvious claims of younger rivals cristiano ronaldo and lionel messi

column8: after his family had moved there

column1: 254	-lrb- cnn -rrb- -- the orgy of violence that has greeted kenya 's disputed election result has led to hundreds of deaths and forced tens of thousands to flee their homes . but away from the tragic human cost
column2: the unrest has also provoked concerns about the stability of the east african country 's economy
column3: until now seen as a model for the region . businesses have been destroyed and looted and supply routes disrupted after the opposition accused incumbent president mwai kibaki of election fraud after he was declared winner sunday . investors are watching events closely in the country

column6: the paper reported . `` we do seem to be in a new place

column8: '' said razia kahn

column11: a growth of 5.2 per cent . however

column13: since around 40 percent of kenya 's exports go to other african nations

column15: coffee
column16: vegetables and flowers are big earners for the country

column1: 267	atlanta
column2: georgia -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- i was 14 at the time . lebanon 's civil war was in full flood . one afternoon the shells began raining down on our neighborhood in beirut . a lebanese woman and her son run through west beirut in 1989 during fighting between rival forces . we ran from school screaming . forget the book bags
column3: classmates
column4: homework . just run . out of breath
column5: my knees giving way
column6: it seemed to take forever to reach our local shelter -- a dark humid room at the back of our apartment block . the memory of that terrifying afternoon receded -- until recently . after more than a decade of relative peace and reconstruction
column7: the bombings and assassinations have returned to beirut . every time i hear of a new explosion
column8: i think of a frightened child sitting in darkness . in 1988
column9: i watched the last throes of lebanon 's civil war firsthand -- and like millions of lebanese
column10: sad
column11: frustrated and often fearful . see a timeline of lebanon 's recent history '' now i watch from another continent
column12: but i find those same emotions resurfacing . the conspiracies
column13: the car bombs
column14: the threatening rhetoric and political deadlock are eerily familiar . the actors are like shadows from a long gone past . they are grayer perhaps -- those who have avoided assassination . but the cast in lebanon 's tragedy has changed little in two decades . then
column15: as now
column16: a presidential election is the setting
column17: and the struggle where religion and clan play the main roles threatens to set lebanon back 20 years . see bios of lebanon 's major players '' in 1988
column18: the president 's term was coming to an end and the warring factions were unable to agree on a new candidate . militias prevented parliament members from reaching the assembly building . compromise was nowhere in sight . the west had abandoned lebanon to the manipulation of its neighbors . syria had its choice for president ; israel had its own allies -- a foil for growing muslim radicalism . the country was awash with weapons . in his last act as president
column19: amin gemayel named fellow christian and army chief michel aoun as prime minister . at a stroke
column20: he shattered the convention that a muslim hold that position . muslims refused to serve in the cabinet and the country ended up with two governments . aoun famously declared : `` i am prime minister and six ministers in one . '' aoun 's `` war of liberation '' against syria turned into defeat . then
column21: he turned on fellow christians of the lebanese forces in the `` war of elimination . '' when that failed
column22: the syrians drove aoun to take refuge at the french embassy . in august 1990
column23: i came to cnn as a world report panelist . i tried to explain lebanon 's chaos
column24: the bewildering array of factions and the horrors of civil war for ordinary civilians . i had seen people killed in front of me ; children orphaned in seconds
column25: parents burying their infants in oversize white coffins . so when i was offered the opportunity to stay at cnn
column26: i gratefully accepted the chance to escape the anarchy . but almost as i left
column27: the civil war was being laid to rest . the various factions had fought each other to a standstill ; arab governments
column28: supported by the west
column29: helped negotiate a new constitutional framework overseen by syrian influence . peace came to lebanon
column30: but it would be five years before i returned . in 1995
column31: i went back and was stunned . i kept looking around for checkpoints manned by militants . i could n't believe that i could go anywhere without being harassed or kidnapped by one faction or another . no longer did identity -- christian
column32: muslim or druze -- define where lebanese could go . people mixed freely in chic coffee shops and smoked the hubble-bubble
column33: laughing at the same jokes . it was as if lebanon 's divisions had been wiped away by some magic eraser . downtown beirut
column34: once rocked by explosions and pitted with bullet holes
column35: was rocking to lebanese pop music . the dusty sandbags had given way to boutiques carrying the latest european fashions and deluxe hotels . lovers had returned to beirut 's corniche
column36: overlooking the mediterranean
column37: for romantic strolls at sunset . but the agreement that ended the civil war was more a truce than a real settlement -- and was overseen by a `` pax syriana . '' as anti-syrian sentiment grew
column38: so did political tensions . on valentine 's day 2005
column39: the corniche was once again rocked by an explosion . former prime minister rafik hariri was killed . the symbolism left me speechless . on the day of love
column40: lebanon was thrown back into its most hateful history . it had been widely expected that hariri would run for office again and demand the withdrawal of syrian troops . suspicion fell on damascus
column41: which vehemently denied involvement . on march 14
column42: martyrs ' square became a human sea of demonstrators : muslims
column43: druze and christians alike
column44: demanding the `` truth . '' but hariri 's death also exposed the fault lines that had broken lebanon a generation previously . even after it withdrew its troops
column45: syria still had allies in lebanon . one was hezbollah
column46: accused of the suicide attacks that had killed scores of u.s. marines in beirut more than 20 years previously . another was gen. michel aoun ; now back from exile
column47: the same michel aoun who had defied syria in 1989
column48: but who now made common cause with hezbollah against his fellow christians . earlier this year i visited martyrs ' square . the spirit of the cedar revolution had evaporated . the place looked like a morgue . anti-government hezbollah squatters had brought life there to a standstill . as i passed through
column49: business owners stood silent in the sun and shook their heads at me in despair . i wondered if they sensed my disappointment
column50: my pain at watching beirut bleed again . lebanon 's political actors now find themselves re-enacting scenes from the final act of the civil war 19 years ago . once again
column51: the term of the president is approaching its end ; there is no agreement on his successor . suspicion and fear are the political currency of the day . and the questions haunts me : will the country 's brief renaissance that so amazed me in 1995 be snuffed out by the old curse of sectarian rivalries ? e-mail to a friend . cnn 's joe sterling
column52: david ariosto
column53: saad abedine and tracy doueiry contributed to this report .

column1: 270	-lrb- cnn -rrb- -- kenya has enjoyed a reputation as one of east africa 's most stable nations since achieving independence from the uk in 1963 . residents of the mathare slum in nairobi shout at demonstrators during violent clashes . but a booming tourism industry

column2: california -- top-seed andy roddick easily defeated delray beach winner kei nishikori of japan 6-2 6-4 in the headline match at the atp tournament in san jose on thursday night . a pumped up roddick needed little over an hour to dispatch teenager nishikori . roddick needed just 63 minutes to defeat the 18-year-old japanese who won his first atp title on sunday and was on an eight-match winning run . but american number one roddick imposed his quality from the start by taking a commanding 3-0 lead and breaking nishikori 's serve before the youngster won a game . roddick
column3: who has won twice in san jose
column4: repeated the break later in a feisty opening set which came to a head in the seventh game . roddick barked at the young player as they exchanged shots at the net . nishikori held his cool
column5: did not respond
column6: and just walked away . `` i did n't understand a word he said
column7: '' nishikori said . but when pressed he acknowledged that he did in fact understand what roddick had shouted at him but just did not want to repeat it before the press . but roddick had no trouble repeating what he had said . `` i told him to stick me with it the next time . i just let him know that he needs to finish it . i had no problem with it . but it was a monologue . '' roddick duly rounded off the set in the next game and broke nishikori 's service in the fourth game of the second only for his youthful opponent to break straight back . but as nishikori served at 4-5 to stay in the tournament he made two crucial errors . he missed an easy slam shot that would have given him the advantage at deuce and then saw his saw his volley go wide that gave roddick the match . `` i made too many easy mistakes

column1: 281	washington -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- president bush on wednesday signed a sweeping energy bill that he said would help the country become `` stronger

'' president bush on wednesday signs a bill raising auto fuel economy standards for the first time in decades . the bill -- approved overwhelmingly tuesday by the house of representatives -- raises automotive fuel economy standards for the first time in more than three decades
column3: requiring a corporate average of 35 miles per gallon by 2020 . it also boosts federal support for alternative fuel research and energy conservation efforts . a republican filibuster in the senate removed provisions that bush objected to that would have eliminated tax breaks for oil companies and a requirement that electric utilities produce a portion of their power from alternative sources . the current fuel-economy standards of 27.5 miles per gallon for passenger cars and 22.2 for light trucks were established in 1975 . the new bill sets a single average standard for manufacturers . senate majority leader harry reid
column4: d-nevada
column5: said tuesday 's bill was `` a great
column6: wonderful first step for an energy revolution that starts in america and ripples throughout the world . '' but reid said democrats would continue pushing to shift federal tax breaks away from fossil-fuel producers and into renewable energy research -- one of the party 's top priorities when it took control of congress in january . house opponents such as rep. joe barton
column7: r-texas

column9: '' said barton
column10: the ranking republican on the house committee on energy and commerce . `` i do not understand how what made sense two years ago does n't make sense today . '' barton called the legislation a `` no-energy '' bill and `` a recipe for recession

column12: homes and appliances for consumers . e-mail to a friend . cnn 's ed henry contributed to this report .

column1: 300	-lrb- cnn -rrb- -- a texas couple charged with killing the little girl known as `` baby grace '' now face capital murder charges

column6: plastic bin . her identity was not known at first

column8: and sheryl sawyers
column9: the girl 's paternal grandmother

column12: and zeigler

column15: in addition to confirming riley 's identity

column19: including police and fbi investigators and the medical examiner . the grand jury deliberated for only three minutes wednesday before upgrading the charges

column1: 302	washington -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- president bush on friday proposed a temporary
column2: broad-based tax relief package aimed at spurring the nation 's slowing economy . `` we can provide a shot in the arm '' to the economy
column3: president bush said friday at the white house . during remarks at the white house
column4: bush
column5: flanked by economic advisers
column6: said the nation 's economy is at risk for a downturn and congress must act to head off trouble . `` this growth package must be big enough to make a difference in an economy as large and dynamic as ours
column7: '' bush said . `` by passing a growth package quickly
column8: we can provide a shot in the arm to keep a fundamentally strong economy healthy
column9: and it will help keep economic sectors that are going through adjustments
column10: such as the housing market
column11: from adversely affecting other parts of our economy . '' watch more of bush 's tax outline '' it should equal about 1 percent of the nation 's gross domestic product
column12: or roughly $ 140 billion
column13: he added . bush said the economy will continue to grow but at a slower rate . the president offered no specific details of the proposed package
column14: but he did insist that it include tax incentives for business
column15: `` including small businesses
column16: to make major investments in their enterprises this year . '' bush also said the economic package must include `` rapid income tax relief '' for consumers to `` lift our economy at a time when people otherwise might spend less . '' although democratic leaders in congress expressed general support for bush 's remarks
column17: other democrats on capitol hill met the president 's proposal with suspicion . two democratic leadership aides made it clear friday that the growth package would not win support from democratic leaders unless it includes relief for low and middle income earners . `` we want to include people who pay taxes
column18: not necessarily income taxes -- a lot of lower income people pay payroll taxes
column19: '' said one aide . another source stated flatly

column21: d-new york

column24: '' schumer said . house speaker nancy pelosi
column25: d-california
column26: expressed agreement with bush on `` the need to provide assistance immediately
column27: '' saying in a statement that `` we must invest our resources in such a way that injects confidence and consumer demand

column29: d-nevada
column30: said
column31: `` i also agree that our focus must be on finding temporary measures that will do the job effectively . '' sen. edward kennedy
column32: d-massachusetts
column33: agreed that `` we must act swiftly to boost the economy '' but stressed the need to help families who `` are struggling every day to pay their bills
column34: heat their homes and pay their mortgages . '' bush 's remarks came a day after talks on the subject with democratic and republican lawmakers
column35: and following federal reserve chairman ben bernanke 's call for a fiscal stimulus package to help an economy beset by plummeting stock prices and a credit and mortgage crunch . bush said friday he was encouraged by his discussions with lawmakers . `` i believe there is enough broad consensus that we can come up with a package that can be approved with bipartisan support . '' existing income tax cuts supported by the bush administration are due to expire in 2010
column36: and the president called on congress to make them permanent . `` unless congress acts

column38: '' bush said . `` this tax increase would put jobs and economic growth at risk . '' watch experts explain how to goose the economy '' the proposed stimulus package comes as a leading gauge of future economic activity was released friday by the conference board . the december report showed a decline for a third straight month for the u.s. leading index -- down two-tenths of a percent . the report cited housing permits for the largest negative contribution to the index . see chart showing americans ' recession fears '' on thursday
column39: the dow jones industrial average of stock prices dropped more than 300 points after reports of slowing growth and massive debt write-offs by merrill lynch . the brokerage giant reported a nearly $ 10 billion loss for the fourth quarter of 2007 and wrote off more than $ 11 billion in bad mortgage debts . former treasury secretary lawrence summers stressed the importance of whom any relief package would target . `` it needs to go to people who are going to spend it

column42: but he said he expects growth to proceed at a slow pace this year and possibly into early 2009 . he said congress needs to take decisive action to boost the economy . `` to be useful

column44: '' bernanke said . but he said any package should be `` explicitly temporary '' to avoid running up the government 's long-term debt . bernanke stopped short of suggesting that the bush tax cuts should be made permanent
column45: telling lawmakers he supports `` the law of arithmetic . '' `` what comes in at least has to equal what goes out at some point
column46: '' he said . in 2001
column47: americans received checks from the government designed to stimulate the economy . individuals received $ 300 and families $ 600 . twenty to 40 percent of the checks were spent within days . consumers saved one-third of the money

column1: 303	tampa
column2: florida -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- after witnessing the rapid devastation of a cayman island coral reef where he had been diving since childhood
column3: todd barber was moved from horror to action . he gave up a six-figure salary as a marketing consultant and dedicated his life to restoring the world 's ocean reef ecosystems . `` i had been following this reef since i had been 14 ; it was where my first dive was
column4: '' recalls barber . `` when that one little tiny reef was lost
column5: that sparked something in me . if we lost one and it took that tens of thousands of years to get here
column6: how fast is this happening ? '' barber had caught a small glimpse of a larger global issue -- the destruction of the world 's coral reefs -- and it scared him . according to the nature conservancy
column7: if the present rate of destruction continues
column8: 70 percent of the world 's coral reefs will be destroyed by the year 2050 . not only are they home to 25 percent of all marine fish species
column9: but the organization states that 500 million people rely on coral reefs for their food and livelihoods . so barber and his father
column10: a marine biologist and fellow diver
column11: sat down to devise a solution to `` put the reef back . '' what started as a basic idea to shape concrete around a beach ball led to three years of research
column12: testing and prototyping with the help of friends and college professors . watch as barber explains his passion for saving reefs '' `` our goal was to mimic nature
column13: not dictate nature
column14: '' says barber . `` and that meant that i could n't come up with an idea ; i had to design something that would fit exactly what the reef required . '' the result was what barber calls a `` reef ball . '' made of concrete engineered to last more than 500 years
column15: reef balls are circular structures with a hollow center that serve as a base habitat upon which a natural reef can grow . portable
column16: inexpensive and environmentally friendly
column17: according to barber
column18: reef balls can be built anywhere and are used to mimic and rehabilitate all forms of oceanic reefs
column19: such as mangrove
column20: oyster and coral reefs . they can also help control erosion and stabilize shorelines . watch as an organization in tampa tries to restore habitats for oysters '' to manufacture and place reef balls in marine habitats around the world
column21: barber established the reef ball foundation in 1993 . today
column22: the non-profit organization works with environmental agencies
column23: universities
column24: community groups and corporations and empowers others to build and restore their local marine ecosystems . '' -lsb- reefs -rsb- have an incredible bearing on human life
column25: '' says barber . `` without conserving these resources
column26: they 're going to be all gone before we even know what we 've lost . '' according to barber
column27: marine conservation is n't just about reef balls
column28: but they 're one important tool . `` it 's about saving natural reefs . it 's about changing our behaviors
column29: '' says barber . `` it 's better to save the reef that you have than to build a new one . '' since its inception
column30: the reef ball foundation has placed reef balls in more than 59 countries . `` for me
column31: personally
column32: the satisfaction comes from diving on a reef ball and seeing that the environment has been rehabilitated ; that the reef is actually there
column33: '' says barber . `` and that our grandkids will be able to see the same thing . '' e-mail to a friend .

column1: 308	washington -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- the u.s. senate was called to order for 11 seconds on wednesday as the last political scuffle of the year between the white house and the democratic-led congress played out . democratic senators will hold short `` pro forma '' sessions over the holiday break to prevent recess appointments . nearly all the senators left the capitol for the christmas holiday last week

column1: 313	london
column2: england -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- valerie gooding is in the top five most powerful businesswomen in europe as named by the financial times . she runs global health and care organization bupa and under her leadership it has grown to over 8 million customers in over 190 countries and record revenues . cnn 's todd benjamin spoke to her in london and began by asking her why there are so few women at the top . she said it goes beyond family issues . gooding : women sometimes do n't put themselves forward for things . and one of the things i think about and talk about a lot is that women often lack confidence to go for the next job
column3: the top job . they sometimes do n't wish to compete or they do n't think they 're good enough for the next thing . benjamin : why do you think that is ? gooding : partly a lack of role models
column4: partly it may be conditioning from a very early age about what the role of women is in society and the family
column5: in work . but also i think there is still -- i do n't like to call it a glass ceiling
column6: but i think there is still an unseen barrier for women
column7: which is that
column8: if you ask most business people
column9: would they like to promote more women
column10: they would all say yes
column11: they 'd love to : `` where are these women
column12: i want to promote them
column13: '' will be the answer . but often they do n't really automatically think of a woman first for a top job . benjamin : and what advice would you give to women who want to try and make it to the top ? gooding : well
column14: first of all
column15: to learn as much as you can and to make sure you 've got the right experience
column16: the right qualifications
column17: and to enjoy each job for its own interest and job satisfaction . but i think another piece of advice i would give to women is not to be afraid to put themselves forward and say what it is they want
column18: because i think one thing that happens with women
column19: which perhaps is a gender difference
column20: is that women often hang back and think `` i will be noticed for my results
column21: everybody will see how great i am because i 've delivered these exceptional outcomes '' . but actually life is n't like that
column22: you have to tell people about your results and your achievements
column23: and men are often better at doing that than women are . benjamin : what do you think separates good leadership from great leadership ? gooding : well
column24: i think good leaders should be judged on their results . and i think of a good leader you should be able to say `` she transformed the business
column25: '' `` she upped the performance
column26: '' `` she exceeded the expectations of the stakeholders . '' i think of a great leader i would go to that old chinese saying
column27: `` of a great leader the people will say `` we did it ourselves '' '' . benjamin : do you think that women in general as managers are more inclusive than men ? gooding : no
column28: i do n't . in fact
column29: i sometimes find these gender differences
column30: when sort of represented in the business environment
column31: are actually just not very useful . i think men and women have very different styles of leadership as individuals and i do n't think it goes down to straightforward gender divide . because i have seen women who are more autocratic and more leading from the front and more dictatorial
column32: and i 've equally seen men who are very consultative . so
column33: i do n't just think it divides that way . benjamin : you clearly love what you do . what is it about business that you think is such a buzz ? gooding : it 's the constant challenge
column34: there 's always something new
column35: there 's a new competitor
column36: there 's a new pressure
column37: there 's a new opportunity
column38: there 's a new challenge
column39: i think that 's what keeps us all going . i think it 's the thrill of the chase
column40: basically . e-mail to a friend .

'' watch a psychologist talk about how spears ' pregnancy could lead to parents talking to their kids about sex '' in louisiana

column1: 325	-lrb- cnn -rrb- -- despite the obvious claims of younger rivals cristiano ronaldo and lionel messi
column2: few can really argue with the 96 football journalists who voted ricardo izecson dos santos leite as the 2007 world footballer of the year . brazilian genius kaka fully deserves winning the 2007 world footballer of the year award . the prestigious ballon d'or award is widely regarded as the most prestigious individual prize in football and kaka 's inclusion on its coveted roll of honor is a testament to the 25-year-old brazilian 's current standing in world football . when ac milan defeated liverpool in the champions league final in athens
column3: avenging their heartbreaking loss to the same team in istanbul two years previously
column4: it enabled kaka to fulfill his dream of holding aloft europe 's premier trophy -- a winner 's medal he fully deserved after a sublime 90-minute performance . kaka 's stock for both club and country has risen steadily since his move to the san siro from sao paulo for a fee of just $ 8.5 million in the summer of 2003 . unlike many a brazilian sporting genius
column5: kaka did not hone his skills on the beach or the streets of a favela shanty town . he was born into a comfortable middle class brasilia family
column6: where football was not the only hope of a bright future . however
column7: it soon became clear that this particular boy had a very special skill and he was signed by sao paulo
column8: after his family had moved there
column9: at just eight years of age -- making his first team debut as an 18-year-old . kaka 's progress was soon picked up by his national team coach and felipe scolari named the graceful midfielder in his 23-man squad for the 2002 world cup finals
column10: earning him a winners ' medal despite playing only 19 minutes of the tournament in a group match against costa rica . a year later
column11: and kaka was on his way to milan . within a month he had made the starting line-up and his 10 goals helped the rossoneri lift the scudetto and the european super cup . throughout his career
column12: kaka has always possessed the innate ability to score goals -- his record for both club and country sees him average roughly a goal every three games . yet to describe kaka merely as a goalscoring midfielder would be doing him a massive injustice . tall
column13: elegant and blessed with astonishing skill
column14: milan and brazil utilize kaka 's ability superbly . milan coach carlo ancelotti soon recognized kaka 's genius
column15: changing his team 's system to a 4-4-1-1
column16: playing the brazilian behind a main target man . with andrea pirlo and gennaro gattuso holding the central midfield area
column17: kaka has a license to roam in behind the lone striker
column18: be it filippo inzaghi
column19: ronaldo or alberto gilardino . and kaka does this with devastating effect
column20: running at the opposition with pace and power
column21: finding defense-splitting passes or shooting from range with deadly accuracy be it from a dead-ball situation or open play . the fly in the ointment for milan comes in the shape of their poor form this season . although they have already reached the last 16 of the champions league
column22: the club are floundering in serie a and face the unthinkable prospect of not qualifying for next season 's competition unless they win the trophy . real madrid have coveted kaka for the last two years -- expect the world transfer record to be smashed if milan do n't secure a place among europe 's elite . e-mail to a friend .

column2: sri lanka -lrb- reuters -rrb- -- humble woodcutter mohammed sultan nafeek 's teenage daughter moved to saudi arabia to work as a housemaid to support her family after they were displaced by the 2004 tsunami . now she is on death row
column3: and all he can do is pray . razeena mohammad -lrb- left -rrb- and mohammad sultan nafeek
column4: parents of rizana nafeek . rizana
column5: who was 17 when she started work in saudi arabia
column6: was convicted of killing a 4-month-old baby boy in her care just two weeks into her job . nafeek says the child died accidentally
column7: choking on milk . his daughter was sentenced to beheading in a case rights groups say underlines the vulnerability of many of the 1.5 million sri lankans who work abroad -- nearly 400
column8: 000 of them in saudi arabia alone . `` our family was suffering hardship
column9: and so our daughter volunteered to go and work abroad to send money home
column10: '' nafeek told reuters by telephone from his modest home in mutur in sri lanka 's war-torn northeast . after the december 2004 tsunami forced them from their home
column11: the family was displaced again by renewed civil war between the state and separatist tamil tiger rebels . nafeek visited saudi arabia with sri lanka 's deputy foreign minister this month in a bid to secure clemency and met with relations of the dead child 's parents but came away empty handed . under saudi law
column12: a pardon is the gift of the family of the victim
column13: and so far the parents of the dead child have refused to meet either the family or sri lankan officials . `` the cops told us : ` go and pray to allah . if you can get the forgiveness of the parents
column14: your daughter will be free
column15: ' '' he said . `` so i am praying all the time . '' `` if we had been able to meet the parents
column16: we are sure they would have been willing to forgive our daughter after seeing our situation . '' the sri lankan government is investigating the agency that sent rizana to work abroad when she was technically still a child but remains hopeful she will be pardoned or exonerated . `` i am fairly confident
column17: '' said deputy foreign minister hussein bhaila . `` we have spoken to tribal leaders of their particular tribe
column18: we have spoken to area officials ... it is they who will now have to speak -lrb- to the parents -rrb- . '' `` his excellency the president -lrb- mahinda rajapaksa -rrb- has been following this case very keenly . this is an exceptional case because of her tender age
column19: '' he added . rights groups accuse the government of failing to protect its expatriate workers -- one of the main sources of foreign-exchange revenues for the $ 23 billion economy -- with legal aid . they also decry saudi arabia 's legal system . `` this case raises many troubling questions about the treatment of children and foreigners in saudi arabia 's criminal-justice system
column20: '' human rights watch said in a statement issued overnight . `` international law prohibits the death penalty for crimes committed before the age of 18 . '' saudi arabia executed four sri lankans convicted of armed robbery earlier this year
column21: and did not inform sri lankan authorities beforehand . sri lanka reinstated its own death penalty in 2004 after the murder of a high court judge
column22: but it has been dormant since 1976 . there is no indication any of the dozens of convicted murderers
column23: rapists and drug smugglers on death row in sri lanka and effectively serving life prison terms will actually be executed . e-mail to a friend . copyright 2007 reuters . all rights reserved.this material may not be published

column5: most likely

column7: the only time we 'll create one is if it 's not being done well . benjamin : how would you describe your own personality ? branson : i love people

column13: congratulations

column16: you 're either going to have to do your school work or your magazine

column21: her approach was to try and get us to stand on our own two feet and she went to extreme measures sometimes to do so . benjamin : without your persona do you think the virgin brand could have ever become what it became ? branson : i think the particular virgin brand perhaps needed me

column1: 350	-lrb- cnn -rrb- -- the orgy of violence that has greeted kenya 's disputed election result has led to hundreds of deaths and forced tens of thousands to flee their homes . but away from the tragic human cost

column1: 369	-lrb- cnn -rrb- -- danish authorities said tuesday they have arrested three people who allegedly were plotting a `` terror-related assassination '' of a cartoonist whose drawing of the prophet mohammed sparked rage in the muslim world two years ago . the cartoons of the prophet mohammed provoked widespread outrage in the muslim world two years ago . the danish security and intelligence service said police arrested a 40-year-old dane of moroccan origin and two tunisians . the danish citizen is charged with a terrorism offense

column13: but the rising age of drivers . aaa points out that seniors are the fastest growing demographic in the u.s. . that suggests drivers should adjust their habits accordingly . aaa has launched its lifelong safe mobility campaign to help seniors adjust to more crowded roads and perhaps more aggressive drivers . the facts and remedy . when the aaa foundation for traffic safety studied more than 10
column14: 000 incidents of road rage and violent aggressive driving committed in the 1990s
column15: it found that at least 218 people were killed and another 12
column16: 610 injured when drivers got angry . many of these aggressors are males aged 18 to 26 . the aaa web site offers a three-step plan to avoid becoming the victim of aggressive driving : .  the first tip is `` do n't offend
column17: '' which includes cutting off other drivers
column18: driving slowly in the left lane
column19: tailgating and gesturing to other drivers .  the agency then warns to `` not engage
column20: '' which advises steering clear of trouble
column21: not making eye contact and getting help
column22: by calling 911
column23: in the event of experiencing dangerous
column24: aggressive driving . it then asks at-risk drivers to `` adjust their attitude
column25: '' which involves `` forgetting winning '' -lrb- for the drivers to whom driving is a darwinian survival of the fittest -rrb-
column26: or putting themselves in the other drivers ' shoes .  finally
column27: they recommend that
column28: if you think you have a road rage problem
column29: seek professional help . other people 's actions . so the wife and i were looking for sofas . it was a sunday morning and
column30: with me behind the wheel
column31: we were dawdling around quiet streets trying to find one of those seemingly ubiquitous furniture warehouses . soon
column32: the wife pointed one out but we were almost past it . i hit the brakes and quickly pulled in
column33: then realized that a mercedes m-class had pulled in right behind me . a large
column34: squat tattooed guy jumped out and started shouting
column35: about 10 feet from my car . `` i have children in the car
column36: i had to slam on the brakes
column37: -lsb- how dare -rsb- you brake so quickly
column38: '' he said
column39: getting real mean . i appreciated i 'd probably braked quickly and that it was bad driving on my part . however
column40: as his tirade continued
column41: i very calmly asked why he was setting such a bad example for his young children by following another driver off the road
column42: then shouting and swearing . the man continued his harangue before climbing back into his vehicle and driving away . the next time you 're fulminating in your front seat about another 's aggressive driving
column43: remember that your driving will almost inevitably elicit the same response in someone else . and do n't swear in front of your kids or set a bad example for them . ` cultural phenomenon ' dr. leon james is a professor of psychology at the university of hawaii and web master of drdriving.org . he is also the co-author of `` road rage and aggressive driving '' with this wife
column44: diane nahl . james began studying driving psychology about 20 years ago after his wife told him her mother thought he took turns too fast . over a period of self-study
column45: he said he was amazed by the mistakes he made and the aggressive thoughts he experienced toward other drivers . he recorded them via his `` speakaloud '' method . using his method on students
column46: he discovered that road rage is a `` cultural phenomenon . '' `` we call the back seat of the car the ` road rage nursery '
column47: where -lsb- young children -rsb- pick up all the driver 's bad habits
column48: '' james said . `` it 's a cultural temper tantrum . '' james said `` local norms '' can play a part . for example
column49: florida drivers yell at each other more than in california
column50: where verbal interplay can be interpreted as road rage in a criminal court . but
column51: in the main
column52: it 's `` drivers trying to deal with their emotions in stressful situations . '' james said that
column53: in his studies
column54: an awareness gap exists in aggressive drivers : when asked about drivers ' habits
column55: respondents suggested that about 85 percent of other drivers drove aggressively
column56: while just 35 percent said they themselves drove aggressively . if you feel your blood boiling frequently behind the wheel
column57: classes like james ' are sprouting all over the nation . addressing road rage . in an ideal world
column58: an increase in drivers would automatically be met by an improvement in infrastructure
column59: and fewer road-rage-inducing distractions . another utopian ideal is for everyone else to drive more considerately . one look at our nation 's crumbling roads tells us that this fantasyland clearly does n't exist . instead of looking outside your car at road conditions or the habits of other drivers

'' fabric / leather protection . these extras are fairly self-explanatory -- the dealer `` treats '' the upholstered or leather seating with a `` protection '' product that make the seats more resistant to stains or scuff marks . `` this can be a good purchase

'' lojack car security system / anti-theft systems : . the folks at lojack car security systems report that a vehicle is stolen every 25 seconds in the u.s. using a car alarm is one way to protect your vehicle . but if you want to go the more high-tech `` tracking '' route
column53: using a security system like lojack may give you more peace of mind . the lojack system

column58: track it and recover it . lojack claims that over 200
column59: 000 vehicles have been recovered worldwide using their system
column60: with over 100
column61: 000 of those in the u.s. `` whether or not this is a purchase you should make depends on various factors . if you live in a high-crime area
column62: a system like this could provide you with peace of mind

column1: 432	ip-455 press release 8 february 2008 the findings of a scotland yard inquiry into how mohtarma benazir bhutto died after being attacked during a political rally in rawalpindi were presented to the government of pakistan today . the bomb explodes near bhutto 's vehicle following a political rally in rawalpindi . the conclusions of the inquiry were outlined in a detailed report handed over to interim interior minister hamid nawaz by detective superintendent john macbrayne
column2: accompanied by a senior official from the british high commission
column3: during a meeting in islamabad . the text of the executive summary of the report is as follows : . on the 27th december 2007
column4: mohtarma benazir bhutto
column5: the leader of the pakistan people 's party -lrb- ppp -rrb-
column6: died as a result of being attacked in rawalpindi
column7: pakistan . following discussions between the prime minister and president musharraf
column8: it was agreed that officers from the metropolitan police counter terrorism command -lrb- so15 -rrb- should support the investigation into ms bhutto 's death . the primary focus of the scotland yard team was to assist the pakistani authorities in establishing the cause and circumstances of ms bhutto 's death . the wider investigation to establish culpability has remained entirely a matter for the pakistani authorities . the so15 team was led by a detective superintendent senior investigating officer
column9: and comprised two forensic experts
column10: an expert in analysing and assessing video media and an experienced investigating officer . the team arrived in pakistan on 4th january 2008 and spent two and a half weeks conducting extensive enquiries . during the course of their work
column11: the team were joined by other specialists from the united kingdom . the uk team were given extensive support and co-operation by the pakistani authorities
column12: ms bhutto 's family
column13: and senior officials from ms bhutto 's party . the task of establishing exactly what happened was complicated by the lack of an extended and detailed search of the crime scene
column14: the absence of an autopsy
column15: and the absence of recognised body recovery and victim identification processes . nevertheless
column16: the evidence that is available is sufficient for reliable conclusions to be drawn . within the overall objective
column17: a particular focus has been placed on establishing the actual cause of death
column18: and whether there were one or more attackers in the immediate vicinity of ms bhutto . the cause of death . considerable reliance has been placed upon the x-rays taken at rawalpindi general hospital following ms bhutto 's death . given their importance
column19: the x-rays have been independently verified as being of ms bhutto by comparison with her dental x-rays . additionally
column20: a valuable insight was gained from the accounts given by the medical staff involved in her treatment
column21: and from those members of ms bhutto 's family who washed her body before burial . ms bhutto 's only apparent injury was a major trauma to the right side of the head . the uk experts all exclude this injury being an entry or exit wound as a result of gunshot . the only x-ray records
column22: taken after her death
column23: were of ms bhutto 's head . however
column24: the possibility of a bullet wound to her mid or lower trunk can reasonably be excluded . this is based upon the protection afforded by the armoured vehicle in which she was travelling at the time of the attack
column25: and the accounts of her family and hospital staff who examined her . the limited x-ray material
column26: the absence of a full post mortem examination and ct scan
column27: have meant that the uk home office pathologist
column28: dr nathaniel cary
column29: who has been consulted in this case
column30: is unable categorically to exclude the possibility of there being a gunshot wound to the upper trunk or neck . however when his findings are put alongside the accounts of those who had close contact with ms bhutto 's body
column31: the available evidence suggests that there was no gunshot injury . importantly
column32: dr cary excludes the possibility of a bullet to the neck or upper trunk as being a relevant factor in the actual cause of death
column33: when set against the nature and extent of her head injury . in his report dr cary states : .  `` the only tenable cause for the rapidly fatal head injury in this case is that it occurred as the result of impact due to the effects of the bomb-blast . ''  `` in my opinion mohtarma benazir bhutto died as a result of a severe head injury sustained as a consequence of the bomb-blast and due to head impact somewhere in the escape hatch of the vehicle . '' given the severity of the injury to ms bhutto 's head
column34: the prospect that she inadvertently hit her head whilst ducking down into the vehicle can be excluded as a reasonable possibility . high explosives of the type typically used in this sort of device
column35: detonate at a velocity between 6000 and 9000 metres per second . this means that when considering the explosive quantities and distances involved
column36: such an explosion would generate significantly more force than would be necessary to provoke the consequences as occurred in this case . it is also important to comment upon the construction of the vehicle . it was fitted with b6 grade armour and designed to withstand gunfire and bomb-blast . it is an unfortunate and misleading aspect of this case that the roof escape hatch has frequently been referred to as a sunroof . it is not . it is designed and intended to be used solely as a means of escape . it has a solid lip with a depth of 9cm . ms bhutto 's injury is entirely consistent with her head impacting upon the lip of the escape hatch . detailed analysis of the media footage provides supporting evidence . ms bhutto 's head did not completely disappear from view until 0.6 seconds before the blast . she can be seen moving forward and to the right as she ducked down into the vehicle . whilst her exact head position at the time of the detonation can never be ascertained
column37: the overwhelming conclusion must be that she did not succeed in getting her head entirely below the lip of the escape hatch when the explosion occurred . how many people were involved in the immediate attack ? there has been speculation that two individuals were directly involved in the attack . the suggestion has been that one suspect fired shots
column38: and a second detonated the bomb . all the available evidence points toward the person who fired shots and the person who detonated the explosives being one and the same person .  body parts from only one individual remain unidentified . expert opinion provides strong evidence that they originate from the suicide bomber .  analysis of the media footage places the gunman at the rear of the vehicle and looking down immediately before the explosion . the footage does not show the presence of any other potential bomber .  this footage when considered alongside the findings of the forensic explosive expert
column39: that the bombing suspect was within 1 to 2 metres of the vehicle towards it rear and with no person or other obstruction between him and the vehicle
column40: strongly suggests that the bomber and gunman were at the same position . it is virtually inconceivable that anyone who was where the gunman can clearly be seen on the media footage
column41: could have survived the blast and escaped . the inevitable conclusion is that there was one attacker in the immediate vicinity of the vehicle in which ms bhutto was travelling . in essence
column42: all the evidence indicates that one suspect has fired the shots before detonating an improvised explosive device . at the time of the attack this person was standing close to the rear of ms bhutto 's vehicle . the blast caused a violent collision between her head and the escape hatch area of the vehicle
column43: causing a severe and fatal head injury . john macbrayne qpm detective superintendent counter terrorism command 1st february 2008 e-mail to a friend .

'' listen to the full interview . `` we were talking about south carolina political history and this was used out of context and twisted for political purposes by the obama campaign to try to breed resentment elsewhere . and you know
column6: do i regret saying it ? no . do i regret that it was used that way ? i certainly do . but you really got to go some to try to portray me as a racist . '' after the phone interview

column12: and if you will be real honest you will also report what the question was and what the answer was . but i 'm not helping you . column1: 443	-lrb- cnn -rrb- -- for two weeks in 1976
column2: nadia comaneci was probably the most recognizable person on the planet . comaneci scored seven perfect 10s in montreal in 1976 . just 14-years-old and standing less than five feet tall
column3: the elfin romanian was the undisputed star of that year 's games in montreal after becoming the first gymnast in history to score a perfect 10 . comaneci finished up with three gold medals and -- just to prove that her initial effort had been no fluke -- seven perfect scores . her initial performance on the uneven parallel bars was greeted with uproar as the three-digit scoreboard
column4: struggling to cope with what had been considered an unachievable feat
column5: flashed up 1.00 . comaneci finished with four perfect 10s and the gold medal on the bars
column6: but it was on the balance beam
column7: one of gymnastics ' most dangerous disciplines
column8: that comaneci truly dazzled . seemingly fearless
column9: comaneci pirouetted and back-flipped her way to two more perfect 10s and her second gold . her final perfect score came in the floor routine as she also collected first place in the overall competition . comaneci 's transformation into an international celebrity -- she appeared on the front covers of time
column10: newsweek and sports illustrated in the same week -- had been as unexpected as it was sudden . yet comaneci had been working towards the olympics ever since she had been picked out as a gymnast of rare talents as a six-year-old growing up in the industrial town of onesti . the reality of life as an olympic champion at home in nicolae ceausescu 's romania however
column11: was not easy . constant surveillance comaneci was honored as a hero of socialist labor on her return home
column12: yet the regime -- terrified that comaneci would defect after enjoying her taste of western celebrity -- kept its greatest star under constant surveillance . four years later
column13: a very different comaneci returned to olympic competition in moscow . as an 18-year-old
column14: she was four inches taller
column15: 20 pounds heavier and suffering from sciatica -- a teenage starlet already starting to fade . still
column16: comaneci was able to retain her gold medal on the balance beam
column17: and collected another one in the floor exercises . but she was also involved in one of the bitterest incidents of the games when she was controversially beaten in the all-round competition by the soviet gymnast yelena davydova . it took the judges 28 minutes to decide the result and
column18: ultimately
column19: it was a lower score from the soviet judge -- perhaps reflecting the worsening relations between the soviet union and its formerly loyal satellite -- that denied comaneci her second straight gold in the event . comaneci retired in 1984
column20: traveling to los angeles that year as a team coach
column21: yet she found it difficult to adjust to a life out of the spotlight . in 1989
column22: a few weeks before the collapse of the ceausescu regime
column23: she defected to the united states
column24: finally settling in norman
column25: oklahoma to run a gymnastics school after marrying u.s. gymnastics star bart conner in 1996 . in 2000 comaneci was named as one of the athletes of the century by the laureus world sports academy . e-mail to a friend .

'' `` i 've been here over 20 years

column2: massachusetts -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- it all started with the flush of an automatic toilet . the terrifying sound marked the beginning of a two-year nightmare for sarah teres as she desperately tried to potty train her daughter molly . molly graduated from potty school four days before her brother
column3: archer
column4: was born . `` it was awful '' teres said . `` we tried everything including bribery and threats . '' teres
column5: the mother of three from andover
column6: massachusetts
column7: hoped her middle child would be toilet trained by the time she was 2 1/2 . two years later
column8: the girl was still in diapers
column9: refusing to use the bathroom . `` i was going crazy
column10: '' teres admitted . `` she would n't poop . she would hold it for days . '' at wits end
column11: teres enrolled molly in the toilet training school at children 's hospital boston . `` by the time the children come in with their families
column12: it has become a power struggle
column13: '' explained dr. alison schonwald
column14: a pediatrician who supervises the `` poop school
column15: '' as it 's affectionately called by staffers . `` the kids kind of dig in their heels and put a line in the sand . '' health minute : watch more on the perils of potty training '' the american academy of pediatrics reports that most children show signs they 're ready to potty train between 18 and 24 months . doctors suggest a child may be ready to start trying if he 's staying dry for at least two hours at a time during the day
column16: walking to and from the bathroom
column17: asking for a diaper change and asking to use the potty . for some kids
column18: the toilet training process can take more than a year
column19: or longer . the six-week program at children 's hospital is one of a handful around the country . kimberly dunn
column20: a pediatric nurse practitioner
column21: has worked with some of the 450 young graduates over the years . she said most of the kids admit they are afraid to use a toilet . `` oftentimes
column22: the parents come in and they want to know why they 're afraid
column23: '' dunn said . `` you could ask the kids until they 're blue in the face and you hardly ever find out why . '' dunn meets with a half-dozen children once a week . she uses books
column24: music and art to help the students overcome their fear of using the toilet . she helps them set small
column25: realistic goals . for instance
column26: she said
column27: week one involved just sitting on the toilet for five minutes . she encourages positive reinforcement and simple rewards such as extra playtime with mom or dad . while dunn works on the kids
column28: psychologist elaine leclair
column29: an instructor at the harvard school of medicine
column30: offers frank advice to the parents in a separate room . `` i just say
column31: ` step back . ' they hate to hear me say this
column32: but i say whatever you 're doing now is not working . you really need to try something different
column33: '' leclair said . she said many parents come to the sessions angry and anxious . `` they come in feeling extremely discouraged
column34: very isolated thinking they are the only ones in the world who have this problem . '' teres acknowledged that 's how she felt . `` imagine my surprise to find out there were thousands of kids who had this problem . '' after years of hiding her daughter 's toilet training troubles from family and friends
column35: the group parenting sessions allowed teres to open up about her frustrations . `` it was like going to betty ford
column36: '' joked teres
column37: who felt she had exhausted all her other options . a majority of the children who attend the children 's hospital class are dealing with constipation issues often caused by delayed toilet training . teres learned that her daughter had a medical condition called encopresis . experts call it a symptom of chronic constipation and say it occurs when a child resists having a bowel movement . youngsters like molly are sometimes given laxatives or other medications to help encourage them to go . schonwald
column38: the author of `` the pocket idiot 's guide to potty training
column39: '' does n't want parents to be discouraged during the process . `` no one goes to college in diapers
column40: right ? everyone will get through this time
column41: as awful as it might feel if you 're struggling . '' she suggested achieving success during potty training has to do with the approach . `` there are three things you can not make a child do : eat
column42: sleep or poop . we find that by decreasing the pressure and expectations that children feel more confident . '' schonwald reminds parents that toilet training `` is not a chore
column43: so keeping it positive from the very beginning is the most important thing . '' if a child is n't using the toilet by the age of 4
column44: she recommends talking with a pediatrician . schonwald also said setbacks during potty training are normal . `` all developmental skills come in spurts with periods of regression . '' after a setback
column45: schonwald advises parents to give their child positive messages that they can succeed by saying
column46: `` so you had some accidents today . we 'll try again tomorrow . '' four months after graduating from `` poop school
column47: '' teres is relieved to report that molly is fully toilet trained . `` you would never know this was an issue
column48: '' said teres . `` she even used an automatic flush toilet the other day . i waited to see her reaction and she was ok . '' e-mail to a friend . judy fortin is a correspondent with cnn medical news . linda ciampa of accent health contributed to this report .

column1: 450	-lrb- cnn -rrb- -- some democrats say they fear their party 's method of picking a nominee might turn undemocratic as neither presidential candidate is likely to gather the delegates needed for the nomination . the democrats ' superdelegate system is supposed to avoid turmoil at the party 's conventions . sens. hillary clinton and barack obama are running neck and neck toward the party 's august convention in denver

column1: 466	longyearbyen
column2: norway -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- a vast underground vault storing millions of seeds from around the world took delivery of its first shipment tuesday . the inside of one of the vaults at the svalbard global seed vault
column3: on a remote island near the arctic ocean . dubbed the `` doomsday vault
column4: '' the seed bank on a remote island near the arctic ocean is considered the ultimate safety net for the world 's seed collections

column6: natural disasters
column7: lack of funding or simply poor agricultural management . norwegian musicians performed tuesday as part of an elaborate opening ceremony marking the opening of the vault

column10: placed the first seeds inside the vault

column12: 000 distinct samples of seeds
column13: with each sample containing a hundred-plus seeds and originating from a different farm or field around the world . in all

column15: filling 676 boxes . the shipment amounts to a 100 million seeds in total
column16: ranging from major african and asian food staples like maize
column17: rice
column18: and wheat to european and south american varieties of eggplant
column19: lettuce
column20: barley
column21: and potato
column22: according to the global crop diversity trust

column27: in the remote svalbard islands between norway and the north pole . building began last year . the united nations founded the trust in 2004 to support the long-term conservation of crop diversity
column28: and countries and foundations provide the funding . `` the seed vault is the perfect place for keeping seeds safe for centuries
column29: '' said cary fowler

column31: seeds for important crops like wheat
column32: barley and peas can last for up to 10
column33: 000 years . '' the vault 's location deep inside a mountain in the frozen north ensures the seeds can be stored safely no matter what happens outside . `` we believe the design of the facility will ensure that the seeds will stay well-preserved even if such forces as global warming raise temperatures outside the facility
column34: '' said magnus bredeli tveiten
column35: project manager for the norwegian government . the vault sits at the end of a 120-meter -lrb- 131-yard -rrb- tunnel blasted inside the mountain . workers used a refrigeration system to bring the vault to -18 degrees celsius -lrb- just below 0 degrees fahrenheit -rrb-
column36: and a smaller refrigeration system plus the area 's natural permafrost and the mountain 's thick rock will keep the vault at at least -4 c -lrb- 25 f -rrb- . the vault at svalbard is similar to an existing seed bank in sussex

column14: like many other gulf currencies

column2: spain -- barcelona 's argentina striker lionel messi will be out of action for six weeks after tearing a muscle in his left leg during tuesday night 's 1-0 champions league victory over celtic . messi is helped off the pitch after injuring his left thigh during tuesday 's 1-0 victory over celtic . the catalan club confirmed on wednesday that messi will miss both legs of barcelona 's champions league quarterfinal encounter . it will also be a race against time for the 2007 world player of the year runner-up to be fit for the semifinals if barcelona get past an opponent who will be named after the draw on march 14 . messi picked up the injury after 34 minutes during barcelona 's victory over the scottish side
column3: which booked their spot in the last eight by easing through 4-2 on aggregate . it is third time in the last three years that messi has had the same injury
column4: the last occasion being on december 15 against valencia
column5: which ruled him out of the ` el clasico ' derby the following week against real madrid . in addition to his chronic problems with his left thigh
column6: messi has had four other significant injuries in the last two years which have caused him to miss a month or more . barcelona coach frank rijkaard has been forced to defend the club 's medical services in the wake of messi 's latest injury . `` to doubt that they are doing their best is an insult . the medical staff and the club in general are working to prevent these sort of problems . they are working hard but there is always a player that can be injured
column7: '' said dutchman rijkaard . messi 's injury reopens the door for thierry henry to claim his place in the starting lineup . the frenchman has rarely impressed since his big-money move from arsenal to the spanish giants last summer . rijkaard also has other options to replace messi on the right flank in the shape of portuguese international deco or teenage mexican winger giovanni dos santos . e-mail to a friend .

'' `` this kind of thing should not happen in a civilized country . it does n't happen in the united states of america . it does n't happen in most world capitals . so the serb government needs to reflect seriously about the responsibility it has under the vienna convention

column18: '' burns said . demonstrators only managed to break into one u.s. embassy building

column1: 503	-lrb- gametap.com -rrb- -- everyone wants to be more physically fit

column14: the balance board is sleek and elegantly designed . ireport.com : send us your wii fit review . it conveys cool asian style with a streamlined appearance . it 's something you would n't mind having in your living room at all . one thing about nintendo : they know how to make hardware that 's rugged but easy on the eyes . getting started with wii fit is a snap

column17: a standard metric many doctors use to determine a person 's overall fitness
column18: which you can track over time . oddly
column19: however

column21: aerobics
column22: strength training
column23: and balance games . you can choose to work through all four in one session or just concentrate on one . if you 've never tried yoga before

column32: for example

column34: you have to `` catch '' tossed hoops

column36: too . wii fit sets a mellow

column1: 516	-lrb- mental floss -rrb- -- we all want to live forever . but
column2: chances are
column3: you 'd rather forego a legacy altogether than have your name be synonymous with a goofy flub like a spoonerism or a dim-witted word like `` dunce . '' you can find a saint under tawdry in the dictionary . for the following eponyms
column4: we ask : did these word-inspiring folks really deserve their drag through the linguistic mud ? 1 . dunce . dictionaries do n't play fair
column5: and john duns scotus is proof . the 13th/14th-century thinker
column6: whose writings synthesized christian theology and aristotle 's philosophy
column7: was considerably less dumb than a brick . unfortunately for scotus
column8: subsequent theologians took a dim view of all those who championed his viewpoint . these `` scotists
column9: '' `` dunsmen
column10: '' or `` dunses '' were considered hairsplitting meatheads and
column11: eventually
column12: just `` dunces . '' 2 . -lrb- slipping a -rrb- mickey . when you have to drug somebody against their will -lrb- hey
column13: you got ta do what you got ta do -rrb-
column14: it just would n't sound right to slip 'em a ricardo
column15: a bjorn
column16: or an evelyn . it 's got ta be a mickey . at the turn of the 20th century
column17: mickey finn was a chicago saloon owner in one of the seediest parts of town -- and he fit right in . finn was known for serving `` mickey finn specials
column18: '' which probably included chloral hydrate
column19: a heavy sedative . after targeted customers passed out
column20: finn would haul them into his `` operating room '' and liberate them of all valuables -lrb- including shoes -rrb- . never a host of the year candidate
column21: this mickey seems to have thoroughly earned his legacy
column22: so do n't hesitate to use it the next time you drug and rob your own customers . 3 . spoonerism . reverend william archibald spooner -lrb- 1844 -- 1930 -rrb- was famous for his muddled one-liners . and though it 's hard to know which ones he actually said
column23: lines such as `` i have a half-warmed fish '' and `` yes indeed
column24: the lord is a shoving leopard '' still prove that the sound-switching flub is pretty charming as far as mistakes go . the spoonerism has even been used as a literary technique by poets and fiction writers
column25: giving spooner little reason to roll over -- or otherwise inarticulately protest -- in his grave . 4 . lynch . although several lynches -lrb- not including david -rrb- have been investigated by inquisitive etymologists
column26: virginia native charles lynch -lrb- 1736 -- 1796 -rrb- is most likely the man behind the murderous word . lynch was a patriot
column27: a planter
column28: and a judge . but when he headed a vigilante court to punish tories -lrb- british loyalists -rrb- during the american revolution
column29: he decided to play the roles of jury and executioner
column30: too . lynch has more than earned his besmirched name . in fact
column31: he did half the besmirching himself by egotistically referring to his actions as `` lynch law '' and `` lynching . '' 5 . shrapnel . while battling napoleon 's army
column32: english general henry shrapnel -lrb- 1761 -- 1842 -rrb- noticed that original-flavor cannonballs just were n't massacring enough enemies for his liking . so
column33: to get more shebang for his shilling
column34: he filled the cannonballs with bullets and exploding charges . these `` shrapnel shells
column35: '' or `` shrapnel-barrages
column36: '' were pretty darn effective
column37: and later designs proved even more successful in world war i. shrapnel did n't get much credit for the `` innovation '' during his lifetime
column38: but he ultimately contributed to enough death and misery that he pretty much deserves to be synonymous with a violent
column39: metallic byproduct of combat . 6 . draconian . a lexis-nexis news search shows that folks are still talking about `` draconian policies
column40: '' `` draconian penalties
column41: '' and
column42: most frighteningly
column43: `` draconian sex rules . '' though athenian lawgiver draco is not entirely confirmed to have existed
column44: if he were real
column45: then around 621 b.c.e.
column46: he instituted two time-honored traditions : 1 -rrb- writing laws down and 2 -rrb- making laws that were batcrap-insane . they include ascribing the death penalty to such atrocities as being lazy
column47: whizzing in an alley
column48: and stealing an apple . apparently
column49: he justified his measures with a sort of non-logic along the lines of
column50: `` jaywalkers deserve to die
column51: and i ca n't do anything worse to mass murderers . so what 're you gon na do ? '' 7 . boycott . in a nutshell ? boycott got boycotted . charles cunningham boycott -lrb- 1832 -- 1897 -rrb- was a retired english army captain who claimed his unwanted fame in 1880 when the irish land league decided to punish him for not lowering his rents . this then-new strategy
column52: which was a mere paragraph in the russian-novel-size saga of irish land reform
column53: was a kind of systematic shunning in which boycott was cut off from servants
column54: supplies
column55: mail
column56: and lifestyle free of death threats . he might have been an evil landlord
column57: but if boycott could see just how successful his name became
column58: he 'd probably be a very sad
column59: regretful
column60: evil landlord . 8 . tawdry . the story of st. audrey -lrb- also known as st. etheldreda -rrb- is a classic example of how bad names happen to good people . st. audrey was the daughter of the king of east anglia -lrb- then the norfolk section of anglo-saxon england -rrb-
column61: who lived a monastery-founding
column62: self-abdicating life . but
column63: when she died of the plague in 679
column64: she was sporting a pretty nasty-looking tumor on her neck
column65: which gossipmongers blamed on her penchant for wearing audacious necklaces in her youth . after her death
column66: silk scarves called `` st. audrey laces '' were sold in her honor at ely 's annual st. audrey 's fair . then the british tendency for dropping letters and syllables took over
column67: and audrey became `` tawdry . '' it was a short trip from there to the dictionary
column68: and tawdry has been synonymous with gaudy ever since . 9 . chauvinism . nicolas chauvin was an early 19th -- century french soldier who was so patriotic and nationalistic
column69: he gave patriotism and nationalism a bad name -- or at least a new name . a slave to the cult of napoleon
column70: chauvin shed his fair share of blood for the emperor . how did napoleon show his appreciation ? by giving chauvin a ceremonial saber
column71: a ribbon
column72: and a pittance of a pension . later
column73: however
column74: french dramatists began basing ber-patriotic characters on chauvin
column75: which paved the way for the soldier 's ultimate reward : a dubious spot in the english language . e-mail to a friend . for more mental_floss articles

column1: 522	atlanta
column2: georgia -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- it 's a neighborhood of shotgun houses painted a rainbow of colors

column7: sipping coffee and taking a look at who was hit the worst in atlanta 's cabbagetown district . it appeared friday night 's 130 mph tornado had delivered its wrath randomly -- some houses were perfectly intact while others were flooded and smashed . `` it 's a sad thing

column11: hung slightly askew . `` i was cooking dinner and the lights started to flicker

column16: a woman named rebecca -- too distraught to speak with a reporter -- carried what belongings she had left out of her rental home

column23: that is something is n't it ? '' he said
column24: then gestured to the church 's bathroom -- a brick yellow outhouse . `` that 's still here though . we 'll be ok . '' he plans to give a sermon on palm sunday and ask his parishioners to pray hard that lack of insurance wo n't force him to close his doors . steven and laura powell
column25: thinking they were in store for a short lightning storm

'' cabbagetown 's houses were built for the workers at the local fulton cotton mill . the mill closed and the neighborhood slid into decay . the renaissance of cabbagetown began when the mill buildings were converted to the trendy fulton cotton mill lofts and the artists and urban pioneers moved in . in addition to hitting the houses

column1: 525	editor 's note : in our behind the scenes series
column2: cnn correspondents share their experiences in covering news and analyze the stories behind the events . cnn 's senior vatican analyst john l. allen jr. is following the pope during his u.s. trip . pope benedict xvi asked pilgrims in st. peter 's square on sunday to pray for the success of his u.s. trip . new york -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- the official motto of pope benedict xvi 's april 15-20 visit to the united states
column3: the first of his papacy

column5: however
column6: its unofficial motto might well be
column7: `` this is not a political event . '' here 's a typical example from early april : `` the pope is not coming to get mixed up in the local political process

column10: in an interview with the national catholic reporter . `` his presence is about something more universal and
column11: at the same time
column12: more personal . '' fear that benedict 's visit might be read through the lens of party politics reflects a key fact of electoral life in america : the `` catholic vote '' matters . to take the most obvious example
column13: if a few heavily catholic counties in ohio had gone the other way in 2004
column14: pundits would today be handicapping the re-election of president john kerry . america 's almost 70 million catholics
column15: representing a quarter of the country 's population
column16: are diverse and divided . they do n't all agree with official church positions
column17: and although catholics were once reliable democrats

column19: such as ohio
column20: pennsylvania
column21: wisconsin and florida
column22: are considered crucial battlegrounds . already in the 2008 race
column23: catholics have made themselves felt . on the democratic side
column24: they 're the biggest single reason sen. hillary clinton is still afloat . so far
column25: the more catholic a state
column26: the better clinton has done . with her back to the wall not long ago in ohio and texas
column27: clinton decisively outpolled sen. barack obama among catholic democrats . in ohio
column28: clinton won the catholic vote by a margin of 63 percent to 36
column29: while in texas it was 62 percent to 38 . clinton is now hoping that catholics will come through for her again in pennsylvania 's april 22 primary . the state 's 3.87 million catholics represent more than 30 percent of the population
column30: and clinton is clinging to a lead despite pennsylvania sen. robert casey 's endorsement of obama . casey is a hero to pro-life catholic democrats
column31: and his backing is apparently helping obama narrow the gap . clinton does better than obama among latinos
column32: who are disproportionately catholic . she 's also winning catholic `` reagan democrats
column33: '' meaning socially conservative blue-collar voters . obama 's recent gaffe
column34: telling a crowd in san francisco
column35: california
column36: that small-town americans were `` clinging to guns or religion '' out of economic frustration
column37: may help cement that advantage . once the democrats settle on a candidate

column39: the presumptive republican nominee
column40: appeals to many catholics because he 's pro-life and has a moderate stance on immigration . yet his willingness to remain in iraq for `` 100 years '' is at odds with the church 's opposition to the war . either clinton or obama could make a strong appeal to catholics on peace-and-justice issues
column41: yet both are out of sync with catholic teaching on issues such as abortion

column43: along with a `` who 's who '' of prominent catholic conservatives . obama has his own `` national catholic advisory council

column46: but he 'll also likely accent peace
column47: concern for the poor and the environment
column48: issues that generally skew to the democrats . watch as cnn 's rosemary church speaks with vatican analyst john allen about the pope 's visit '' any political fallout may thus depend on what happens to the pope 's message once it 's swept up into the sausage grinder of american spin . benedict xvi usually speaks not in sound bites but in carefully crafted paragraphs
column49: which sometimes leaves the door ajar for competing explanations of what he really means . one can expect a `` war for the microphone '' among republican and democratic operatives
column50: each looking to exploit pieces of the pope 's message . in a tight race
