column1: 902	washington -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- justice department officials blocked liberals and people with democratic party ties from a highly selective program that funneled young lawyers into government jobs
column2: according to an internal investigation released tuesday . a bias against liberals existed in a justice program meant to hire young lawyers
column3: an investigation found . esther slater mcdonald
column4: a political appointee at the justice department
column5: `` wrote disparaging statements about the candidates ' liberal and democratic party affiliations on the applications she reviewed and ... she voted to deselect candidates on that basis
column6: '' said the report by inspector general glenn fine . mcdonald
column7: who has left the department
column8: refused to be interviewed for the investigation . the report
column9: the first official investigation to document politicization of the justice department during the bush administration
column10: is an offshoot of the larger investigation of justice department politics triggered by the furor over the firing of nine u.s. attorneys . it found two of three members of a screening committee considered political views and experience when choosing new lawyers for the justice department honors program and summer law intern program . the report found that mcdonald and michael elston
column11: the chief of staff to deputy attorney general paul mcnulty
column12: engaged in misconduct
column13: an administrative violation . the third member of the screening committee
column14: career lawyer dan fridman
column15: was cleared of any involvement in the politicization of the process . elston was interviewed by the investigators
column16: who asked him about the role of former justice department official monica goodling in politicizing the selection process . elston told investigators he could not recall goodling telling him to select lawyers who appeared to share attorney general alberto gonzales ' philosophy . goodling testified before a house panel last year that she had told elston he should identify such candidates . goodling directed elston to lead the selection committee in 2006 . she and elston have both left the justice department . she refused to be interviewed for the inspector general 's report . as a result of the controversy
column17: the hiring process was changed in 2007 to insulate hiring decisions from political considerations . both justice department policy and federal law prohibit discrimination in hiring for career positions on the basis of political affiliations . the report did not find clear evidence that an earlier screening committee took political considerations into account . it says data from 2002 shows a disparity in the hiring of liberal and conservative candidates
column18: but there were no complaints about the committee 's work from 2003 to 2006
column19: when goodling put elston in charge of the process . the report tuesday is the first of perhaps several to be issued as the broad-ranging investigation into the role partisan politics has played in the justice department during the bush administration . goodling is expected to be a central figure in later inspector general reports examining efforts to increase the influence of conservatives in the department . the justice department office of professional responsibility
column20: a separate watchdog office that monitors prosecutorial conduct
column21: joined in the inspector general 's investigation . cnn 's terry frieden contributed to this report .

column1: 909	join roland martin for his weekly sound-off segment on cnn.com live at 10:30 a.m. et wednesday . if you 're passionate about politics
column2: he wants to hear from you . roland martin says journalists do n't serve the public if they push rumors . -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- two recent stories are a prime example of how important it is for the media to confront the reality of rumors in the age of the internet . one week before comedian bernie mac passed away
column3: text messages and e-mails were flying all over the country with reports that he had died . i was in new york
column4: and friends and colleagues from chicago
column5: illinois
column6: to dallas
column7: texas
column8: and los angeles
column9: california
column10: were saying they knew for sure that the 50-year-old comedian was dead . the rumor mill was so hot that his publicist had to release a statement making it clear that he was not dead
column11: which was subsequently published by the chicago sun-times . what makes this story important is that it was left to the publicist and the family to decide to quash the rumor with the truth
column12: and it was our job in the media to go with the news because it was the latest information made available regarding his condition . then there is the `` rumor '' of an affair by former north carolina senator and two-time presidential candidate john edwards . the story was broken by the national enquirer after months of digging . ultimately
column13: a source came forward and was likely paid for the information that blew the lid off of the story ; the tabloid 's editor said `` you can assume '' the enquirer paid for it . the story exposed edwards as a liar for contending for two years that such an affair never happened . there has been a lot of hand wringing about why a major media outlet was n't able to verify the story and run with it . the heated discussions even reached the point where charlotte observer editor rick thames told pbs ' `` newshour with jim lehrer '' that since mainstream media no longer has the news cycle to itself
column14: `` when rumor arises
column15: we 're going to need to address it . and
column16: unfortunately
column17: we may need to address it before we can determine whether it 's true or not because it 's having impact
column18: as it was in this case . '' sorry
column19: rick
column20: i disagree . the most fundamental aspect of being a journalist is that we do n't traffic in rumor and innuendo . none of us serves the public if we are in the business of pushing unverified stories into print or on the airwaves just so we can keep up with a rumor that is out of control . running with such rumors has far-reaching implications . just check out this month 's vanity fair
column21: where bryan burroughs has a great story on the collapse of bear stearns . the investment bank 's demise
column22: some conclude
column23: was all a result of baseless rumors suggesting the company had cash problems
column24: even though it was sitting on $ 18 billion . the rumors kept going and going and when the story hit the airwaves
column25: it spread like wildfire . in one week
column26: bear stearns was no more
column27: and former company executives are still trying to determine what killed the wall street behemoth . we should forget the nonsense about the competitive pressure to break the story . the rules are simple : either you have the facts or you do n't . if you do
column28: you run with the story . if you do n't
column29: you leave it alone . the national enquirer got the story because its reporters were able to confront edwards as he was leaving the beverly hills hotel room of the woman with whom he later admitted having an affair . then the paper got its hands on what it said was a photo of the 2004 democratic vice presidential nominee playing with a baby the enquirer said was the child of the mistress . with other major media outlets turning up the heat
column30: edwards admitted the affair in an interview with abc 's bob woodruff . no media executive should be pulling his or her hair out
column31: trying to figure out why they chose not to spread the rumor . if they had
column32: and the facts did n't support the rumor
column33: then we would all look like fools and that would have angered the public even more . we have an obligation to stick with the facts
column34: and nothing else . and no matter what a blogger
column35: web site or tabloid paper has decided to run with
column36: the day we choose to alter our standards
column37: our credibility and integrity will be shot . in the end
column38: as former abc news anchor max robinson said in 1988
column39: that 's all we 've got . nothing is worth losing that
column40: even getting the scoop on an affair involving a candidate whose political career is likely over . roland s. martin is an award-winning journalist and cnn contributor . he is the author of `` listening to the spirit within : 50 perspectives on faith . '' please visit his web site at http://www.rolandsmartin.com/ . the opinions expressed in this commentary are solely those of the writer .

column1: 928	editor 's note : reese witherspoon
column2: the academy award-winning actress
column3: is honorary chairman of the avon foundation and is employed by avon products as its global ambassador . reese witherspoon says she wants to banish the myth that young women are not at risk for breast cancer . -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- every three minutes in the united states
column4: a woman is diagnosed with breast cancer . as a woman
column5: a mother
column6: and a daughter
column7: i find that statistic terrifying . i was never nave about breast cancer

column9: '' i felt vulnerable and scared as i realized that anyone is susceptible . the only way for me to ease my fears was to take action . i needed to educate myself and others on this disease . as the honorary chair for the avon foundation
column10: i had resources at my fingertips . i had access to an entire organization that is dedicated to giving back to women and educating people . so i started asking

column12: there is a 97 percent five-year survival rate when breast cancer is caught before it spreads to other parts of the body . when breast cancer first develops
column13: there are usually no symptoms
column14: which is why women need to perform self-exams regularly and contact their doctor upon noticing even the smallest change . of course talking about breast cancer and breast health is a personal thing . i too am a private person but encourage all women to break through their reservations and talk to their doctors and physicians . we must also banish the myth that young women are not at risk for breast cancer . at the avon walk in washington

column17: myself
column18: my children and future generations of women
column19: so one day we will not have to be afraid of breast cancer . i began my fight by learning important first steps in breast cancer detection
column20: and will not end my fight until every woman can stand together saying we are breast cancer free . more than anything else

column23: screaming for action to find a cure . avon 's next walk will take place in new york city on october 4 and 5 .

column2: robert rogers was driving home with his family from a wedding when a flash flood took his wife and four children from him in an instant . robert and melissa rogers with their four children before they died in august 2003 . rainfall from a torrential downpour swept the rogers ' minivan off a kansas highway . as water filled the van

column6: and daughter

column11: nicholas

column23: '' he said . in addition to his speaking tours
column24: rogers has established a ministry dedicated to serving orphans across the world . rogers also traveled to haiti and tsunami-ravaged parts of asia to minister and deliver aid to orphans . watch rogers talk about his ministry '' his mission is to establish five orphanages in five continents to symbolize the five family members he lost . one

column27: where eight orphan teens live with a married couple

column29: '' rogers said . since that fateful day five years ago

column31: he hopes his story will inspire others to live each day to its fullest . `` we are not guaranteed the next five seconds
column32: '' rogers said . `` life is very fragile and i hope my stories and inspirations are compelling people to live that life of no regrets . '' cnn 's kyra phillips contributed to this report .

column1: 935	boise
column2: idaho -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- firefighter jonathan frohreich had never heard of the wildland firefighter foundation
column3: much less its founder
column4: until recovering from severe work-related injuries last month . vicki minor 's wildland firefighter foundation has granted more than $ 1.5 million in aid to more than 500 families . as he lay in his hospital bed in sacramento
column5: california
column6: vicki minor put her hand on his shoulder . `` she introduced herself and told me that she was there to help
column7: '' recalls frohreich
column8: who had been in a helicopter crash that killed nine of his colleagues . `` she just said
column9: ` anything . ' she was there to do anything for me . '' since 1999
column10: minor has dedicated herself to providing emergency assistance and ongoing support to injured and fallen wildfire fighters and their families nationwide through her wildland firefighter foundation . wildland firefighters are called into action when the united states ' vast natural resources are threatened by fire . for frohreich
column11: minor 's foundation supplied lodging and food for family and friends who visited his bedside . it also provided emergency funds for medical and other expenses
column12: arranged for frohreich to meet with firefighters who carried him to safety
column13: and brought his fallen comrades ' family members to a bereavement ceremony . `` she means everything
column14: '' frohreich said . `` she 's one of the best things to ever happen . '' minor first became involved with the wildland firefighter community 21 years ago after witnessing a wildfire for the first time . `` i had never seen anything like it
column15: '' minor recalls of the blaze in the mountains of idaho . `` all those firefighter units mobilized in camps that cropped up . it was like an invasion
column16: and i was mesmerized . '' minor started a fire camp commissary
column17: providing dry goods
column18: clothing and necessities to the firefighters . but it was n't until tragedy struck in 1994 at storm king mountain
column19: colorado
column20: where 14 firefighters perished in a single day
column21: that minor was overcome with a need to assist the families . the storm king fire was a turning point . `` fighting fire is much like fighting a war . there 's no time to tend to the injured
column22: or tend to the dead . the fire does n't stop raging
column23: '' minor said . `` i looked up at the heavens and i said to those kids
column24: ` help me help your families . ' '' grieving wildland families
column25: like those of fallen soldiers
column26: tend to be young and scattered throughout the country
column27: often enduring their sudden loss in isolation from their firefighting community . taking cues from a visit to the vietnam veterans memorial in washington
column28: d.c.
column29: minor spearheaded fundraising efforts for the erection of the wildland firefighters monument in boise
column30: idaho
column31: which contains markers `` for almost every wildland firefighter that has fallen
column32: '' minor said . `` i had seen and felt the healing of those combat veterans that would touch a name of their friend
column33: '' minor said . `` our wildland firefighters had nothing like that to process their grief . i wanted to create a place where our families could congregate
column34: reach out in solidarity and comfort to honor their fallen and injured . '' watch minor describe the sculptures in the firefighter monument '' since 1999
column35: the foundation has continued to grow
column36: assisting more than 500 wildland firefighters and their families with more than $ 1.5 million in emergency funds and services
column37: including communication support ; travel and lodging for the injured and fallen ; and emotional and benefit counseling and advocacy . watch minor describe how her foundation takes action to aid wildfire fighters '' `` there is a need for these families to be taken care of
column38: and a long-term need
column39: '' minor said . `` but most of it is to maintain that home until benefits come in . '' when survivors suddenly lose their income and do n't know how to apply for the compensation they 're entitled to
column40: minor 's foundation steps in to guide them
column41: often fighting for them when benefits are delayed or denied . watch minor explain why her foundation fights for firefighters and their families '' minor says she hopes the wildland firefighters know `` we have their back . '' `` i hope that they feel they can go on and fight that fire and know that we 'll take care of their family and their friends . ''

column1: 942	-lrb- oprah.com -rrb- -- on any given day here at `` o
column2: the oprah magazine
column3: '' there are somewhere in the neighborhood of 69 very talented
column4: extremely detail oriented
column5: high-energy
column6: hardworking women and men all doing their jobs and doing them well . i love a few of them

column9: the saruman to my frodo
column10: the dr. octopus to my spiderman . i call her the tinkler . it 's a typical tuesday ; the office is humming along . i 'm answering e-mails
column11: writing cover lines
column12: scheduling a dental appointment here
column13: partial highlights there
column14: kicking myself for not getting sushi at lunch . the sun is shining
column15: the color printer is working -- my life is good . i mosey into the ladies ' room

column17: remind myself that fluorescent lights make everyone look as if they 're in the final stages of tuberculosis
column18: and head for a stall . and then i see it : the seat
column19: even the floor
column20: is covered in little yellow droplets . the tinkler strikes again . to date
column21: i have been able to deduce only four things about her : . 1 . she is female . 2 . she attacks between the hours of 10 a.m. and 8 p.m. 3 . she works alone . 4 . she was raised in a barn . i 've been her victim more times than i can count
column22: and it has turned me from a happy-go-lucky columnist into a bitter
column23: paranoid germaphobe . she has become the bane of my existence . we live in a world where our soldiers lack sufficient body armor
column24: where rupert murdoch is blurring the line intended to keep the business and political interests of media owners from influencing the presentation of news
column25: where the white house still refuses to respond to questions they promised to answer as soon as the scooter libby case was closed
column26: where studies indicate that worrying you 're going to get sick will actually get you sick -- and yet i am devoting an entire column to the tinkler . any shrink worth his or her salt will tell you that it is a mistake to think of your colleagues as family . but what is a family if not a group of people who care about you and irritate you and show up for cake on your birthday and look at pictures of your kid even when they do n't feel like it and think it would n't kill you to put on a little makeup and a pair of heels once in a while ? i 've been earning a paycheck for 30 years . whether rinsing conditioner off a lhasa apso during my stint as shampoo girl at mr. whiskers pet boutique or breathing on the chicken breast i was about to serve a rude diner during my waitressing days

column28: their opinions
column29: their style influence my life . they 've appreciated me

column17: guatemala

column1: 979	editor 's note : two-time oscar winner denzel washington joined the mt. vernon boys & girls club in new york at the age of 6 and remained an active member for the next 12 years . the actor credits his early years spent at the club with changing the direction of his life . since 1994
column2: he has served as a volunteer national spokesman for boys & girls clubs of america
column3: appearing in public service announcements on television and in print . he 's also a member of the group 's board . denzel washington says america 's leaders need to pay attention to the crisis affecting our children . -lrb- cnn -rrb- -- with the political season in full swing
column4: much is at stake for america . the economy is in a downward spiral . we have an energy crisis . our jobless rate is on the rise . these are the subjects that generate headlines and much debate among the candidates . but there is an underlying problem that we as a nation have not addressed
column5: a situation that should concern any american with an eye on the future
column6: regardless of party affiliation . it is the crisis affecting our children : .  nearly 30 percent of this year 's freshman class will drop out of high school
column7: according to the national center for education statistics . that number jumps to 40 percent in some urban areas .  the obesity rate for our kids has gone up by as much as 300 percent since 1980
column8: according to the national center for health statistics
column9: triggering a host of health-related problems
column10: from diabetes to heart disease .  young people account for more than 20 percent of violent crimes in the united states
column11: according to statistics cited by duke university 's center for child and family policy . violent juvenile crime peaks between 3 and 4 p.m.
column12: at the end of the school day . these facts are grim enough . factor in persistent patterns of poverty
column13: gang activity
column14: drug abuse and teenage pregnancy
column15: and you have a generation of americans that will be unprepared -- indeed
column16: unable -- to meet the challenges posed by a complex world . we expect our leaders to lead . but as citizens
column17: we should n't simply sit back and hope that politicians stand up to the test . we can participate in the political process
column18: advocating for policies that will benefit the health
column19: education and well-being of young americans
column20: because we must do a better job of preparing our youth to lead . it is daunting to think about solving such a widespread crisis . but there are youth-serving organizations that can and do play a key role in effecting positive change -- places such as boys & girls clubs
column21: with a long track record of helping young people turn things around
column22: get an education
column23: lead healthy lives and become effective leaders . i know
column24: because i was one of those kids . club staff taught me right from wrong and made the lesson stick . they planted the seeds early on that led me to envision myself as a high school graduate
column25: a college graduate and an achiever in whatever field i chose . boys & girls clubs do this today for millions of kids

column1: 993	-lrb- mental floss -rrb- -- there have been presidential daughters almost as long as there have been presidents . -lrb- george washington had no children . -rrb- . president warren harding made child-care payments to his mistress for years until his death in 1923 . what these women did -- both under the influence of and independent from their influential fathers -- make fascinating stories . here are five you might not have heard : . 1 . sarah knox taylor davis . she packed a lot of drama into her 21 years . the second daughter of future u.s. president zachary taylor

column6: '' now thought to be malaria . sarah survived
column7: but her older and younger sisters died . the taylors were stationed at fort crawford -lrb- now prairie du chien
column8: wisconsin -rrb- in 1832
column9: when sarah met and fell in love with a young officer named jefferson davis . zachary taylor opposed the relationship
column10: and accounts vary as to why -- because he did n't want his daughter to continue to be exposed to the hardships of army life

column13: in louisville
column14: kentucky . sarah 's parents did not attend . once again there is disagreement over why they were absent . the newlyweds immediately headed south
column15: and they visited davis 's relatives in louisiana . sarah
column16: mindful of the family tragedy the last time the taylors traveled those parts
column17: wrote home
column18: `` do not make yourself uneasy about me
column19: the country is quite healthy . '' but while staying with davis 's oldest sister at `` locust grove '' in west feliciana parish
column20: louisiana
column21: the couple fell ill with malaria . jefferson davis recovered
column22: but sarah died

column24: president benjamin harrison
column25: and the television age

column27: four years after her father left office . a widower with two children by his first wife
column28: harrison had married mary scott lord dimmick

column30: the last of the bearded presidents
column31: passed away . if elizabeth 's dynastic 1921 marriage to james blaine walker -- grandnephew of her father 's secretary of state and onetime republican presidential nominee james g. blaine -- was conventional

column33: she had received several academic degrees

column38: it offered economic and investment tips

column40: later
